awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Towards An Optimization-Based and Experimentally Verified Predictive Theory of Human Locomotion
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Develpment (CAREER) award is to obtain a sufficiently accurate, and broadly applicable, predictive theory of how people walk, run, and stabilize their movements. It is already possible to predict some aspects of human walking and running, by computing motions that minimize energy consumption. However, it is not known if such minimization can simultaneously predict the results of many different experiments, or the differences between different subjects. The PI will use large-scale inverse optimization to try to deduce a single objective function, perhaps loosely correlated with energy use, which, when minimized in the context of a computer model of the human-body, predicts the outcomes of many different experiments. The proposed project has four inter-related pieces: (1) Consolidation of locomotion data under a variety of situations: different speeds, inclines, body changes like addition of masses, etc; (2) Inverse optimization to infer the objective function which when minimized, simultaneously explains a substantial fraction (but not all) of the collected data; (3) Forward optimization to predict behavior in locomotor situations not used in the inverse optimization; and (4) Predict responses to perturbations using optimality and compare with perturbation experiments.
 
An accurate and broadly applicable theory of human locomotion will, for instance, enable the systematic model-based design of prosthetic and orthotic devices, and inform the diagnosis and treatment of movement pathologies, including possibly guiding surgical interventions. The project will integrate the research into a number of educational activities, aimed at different student groups, from K-12 to graduate students. The PI will work with OSU's Women in Engineering program to create an educational module for female high school students, targeted at increasing their likelihood of pursuing further education in the STEM disciplines.  These educational modules will emphasize the interplay between mathematical theories, computer simulations, and experiments in science and engineering, and in improving the quality of human life.

por.por_cntn:
Humans walk and run with great effectiveness in a variety of circumstances: on level ground, on treadmills, on slopes and stairs, on uneven terrain, on slippery slope, in buildings and built environments, etc. Our objective here was to obtain a broadly predictive experimentally-verified theory of human locomotion. 

 

First, we tested the hypothesis that humans walk and run in a manner that minimize energy consumption, not just in steady locomotion at a constant speed, but also under a variety of more complex or otherwise unconventional circumstances, substantially extending the range of applicability of this theory. For instance, we showed that humans walk in a manner that minimize energy in novel unpracticed tasks such as walking sideways. We performed novel experiments to measure the energy cost of changing speeds and then showed that humans walk slower for short distances to save energy. We performed novel experiments to measure the energy cost of turning and then used this to produce a coherent account of a variety of phenomena and experiments involving walking with turning: walking in curves, turning in place, turning in a corridor, path planning, etc. We showed that humans walking energy-optimally on a shaky surface may end up shaking it, providing one explanation of why human walking shakes a bridge. We showed that in a popular task used to understand human learning, namely walking on a split-belt treadmill (the two feet are on different belts at different speeds), a simple computer model of a person walking to minimize energy explains how humans learn to eventually walk. We showed that even human responses to sudden unforeseen perturbations while standing or walking may be approximately predicted by determining the response that helps them recover (i.e., not fall down) with the least energy or effort. 

 

In most of the studies described above, we had a close coupling between novel human subject experiments, model-based predictions or inferences, and model predictions tested by further human subject experiments. In cases where energy optimality did not precisely predict human movement, we produced methods that can optimize other quantities such as stability and also obtaining those objectives, which when optimized, explains the observed behavior. In addition to such optimality-based predictive models, we also proposed and employed methods to create predictive models of human locomotion that are data-based but constrained by the physics.

 

We have presented our work at robotics conferences, biomechanics conferences, at interdisciplinary conferences at the intersection of multiple communities, in international peer-reviewed publications, to high school students, and the general public, ensuring broad dissemination of the work and approach. In addition to numerous research articles, the project supported seven Masters or PhD theses in part, providing an opportunity to train the next generation of interdisciplinary engineers/biomechanists. The PI incorporated the methods used in or created through this project in his courses and organized or hosted three conferences/workshops on these topics. The educational aspect of the grant contributed to increasing STEM participation by working with the university's Women in Engineering organization to host a hands-on module in biomechanics and human locomotion for female high-school students, repeated over multiple years. Other broader impacts of the project are that these methods and principles are useful for a variety of applications including the design of assistive or prosthetic devices, designing human-structure interaction and other human-interactive products, understanding gait disorders and designing rehab protocols, etc.
